arm_group.arm_group_label: negative pressure dressing vs. standard of care
arm_group.description: single arm study- randomized Prevena vac or standard of care

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the study is to determine the effects of Prevena therapy on decreasing groin
      surgical site infections in patients who are obese and /or diabetic having vascular surgery.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Prevena Therapy on Obese and or Diabetic Patients With Surgical Groin Sites

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients who are obese and/or diabetic may have poor surgical healing and infection rates
      higher. The PREVENA therapy will be used to evaluate possible reduction of infection rates
      in this patient population

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  subjects over 18 years old

          -  obese (BMI > 30) and or diabetic

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  current infected surgical field, hemodialysis, immunosuppressive therapy, allergy to
             adhesive, sensitivity to silver

intervention.arm_group_label: negative pressure dressing vs. standard of care
intervention.other_name: randomized 1:1 negative pressure dressing vs. standard of care

facility.name: Ohio State Division of Vascular Diseases and Surgery

clinical_study.official_title: EFFECTS OF PREVENA THERAPY ON REDUCTION OF GROIN SURGICAL SITE INFECTIONS IN OBESE PATIENTS UNDERGOING VASCULAR SURGERY

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.description: reduction of 30 day surgical site infection by evaluating infection rates in obese, diabetic patients who were randomized to Prevena Vac vs. standard of care

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: reduction of 1 year graft infection in prosthetic grafts and reduction of secondary hospitalizations for infection.Patients will be followed through 1 year to measure results of infection rates and secondary hospitalization related to infection

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
